segment.source: description: Provides a unique identifier for markup elements.
segment.target: description: Provides a unique identifier for markup elements.

segment.source: For Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML, this unique identifier is used by XAML localization processes and tools, such as using resources from a .resw resource file.
segment.target: For Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML, this unique identifier is used by XAML localization processes and tools, such as using resources from a .resw resource file.

segment.source: title: x:Uid directive'
segment.target: title: x:Uid directive'

segment.source: x:Uid directive
segment.target: x:Uid directive

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Provides a unique identifier for markup elements.
segment.target: Provides a unique identifier for markup elements.

segment.source: For Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML, this unique identifier is used by XAML localization processes and tools, such as using resources from a .resw resource file.
segment.target: For Universal Windows Platform (UWP) XAML, this unique identifier is used by XAML localization processes and tools, such as using resources from a .resw resource file.

segment.source: XAML attribute usage
segment.target: XAML attribute usage

segment.source: XAML values
segment.target: XAML values

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: stringID
segment.target: stringID

segment.source: A string that uniquely identifies a XAML element in an app, and becomes part of the resource path in a resource file.
segment.target: A string that uniquely identifies a XAML element in an app, and becomes part of the resource path in a resource file.

segment.source: See Remarks.
segment.target: See Remarks.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: Use x:Uid to identify an object element in your XAML.
segment.target: Use x:Uid to identify an object element in your XAML.

segment.source: Typically this object element is an instance of a control class or other element that is displayed in a UI.
segment.target: Typically this object element is an instance of a control class or other element that is displayed in a UI.

segment.source: The relationship between the string you use in x:Uid and the strings you use in a resources file is that the resource file strings are the x:Uid followed by a dot (.) and then by the name of a specific property of the element that's being localized.
segment.target: The relationship between the string you use in x:Uid and the strings you use in a resources file is that the resource file strings are the x:Uid followed by a dot (.) and then by the name of a specific property of the element that's being localized.

segment.source: Consider this example:
segment.target: Consider this example:

segment.source: To specify content to replace the display text Go, you must specify a new resource that comes from a resource file.
segment.target: To specify content to replace the display text Go, you must specify a new resource that comes from a resource file.

segment.source: Your resource file should contain an entry for the resource named "GoButton.Content".
segment.target: Your resource file should contain an entry for the resource named "GoButton.Content".

segment.source: Content in this case is a specific property that's inherited by the Button class.
segment.target: Content in this case is a specific property that's inherited by the Button class.

segment.source: You might also provide localized values for other properties of this button, for example you could provide a resource-based value for "GoButton.FlowDirection".
segment.target: You might also provide localized values for other properties of this button, for example you could provide a resource-based value for "GoButton.FlowDirection".

segment.source: For more info on how to use x:Uid and resource files together, see Quickstart: Translating UI resources.
segment.target: For more info on how to use x:Uid and resource files together, see Quickstart: Translating UI resources.

segment.source: The validity of which strings can be used for an x:Uid value is controlled in a practical sense by which strings are legal as an identifier in a resource file and a resource path.
segment.target: The validity of which strings can be used for an x:Uid value is controlled in a practical sense by which strings are legal as an identifier in a resource file and a resource path.

segment.source: x:Uid is discrete from x:Name both because of the stated XAML localization scenario, and so that identifiers that are used for localization have no dependencies on the programming model implications of x:Name.
segment.target: x:Uid is discrete from x:Name both because of the stated XAML localization scenario, and so that identifiers that are used for localization have no dependencies on the programming model implications of x:Name.

segment.source: Also, x:Name is governed by the XAML namescope concept, whereas uniqueness for x:Uid is controlled by the package resource index (PRI) system.
segment.target: Also, x:Name is governed by the XAML namescope concept, whereas uniqueness for x:Uid is controlled by the package resource index (PRI) system.

segment.source: For more info, see Resource Management System.
segment.target: For more info, see Resource Management System.

segment.source: UWP XAML has somewhat different rules for x:Uid uniqueness than previous XAML-utilizing technologies used.
segment.target: UWP XAML has somewhat different rules for x:Uid uniqueness than previous XAML-utilizing technologies used.

segment.source: For UWP XAML it is legal for the same x:Uid ID value to exist as a directive on multiple XAML elements.
segment.target: For UWP XAML it is legal for the same x:Uid ID value to exist as a directive on multiple XAML elements.

segment.source: However, each such element must then share the same resolution logic when resolving the resources in a resource file.
segment.target: However, each such element must then share the same resolution logic when resolving the resources in a resource file.

segment.source: Also, all XAML files in a project share a single resource scope for purposes of x:Uid resolution, there is no concept of x:Uid scopes being aligned to individual XAML files.
segment.target: Also, all XAML files in a project share a single resource scope for purposes of x:Uid resolution, there is no concept of x:Uid scopes being aligned to individual XAML files.

segment.source: In some cases you'll be using a resource path rather than built-in functionality of the package resource index (PRI) system.
segment.target: In some cases you'll be using a resource path rather than built-in functionality of the package resource index (PRI) system.

segment.source: Any string used as an x:Uid value defines a resource path that begins with ms-resource:///Resources/ and includes the x:Uid string.
segment.target: Any string used as an x:Uid value defines a resource path that begins with ms-resource:///Resources/ and includes the x:Uid string.

segment.source: The path is completed by the names of the properties you specify in a resources file or are otherwise targeting.
segment.target: The path is completed by the names of the properties you specify in a resources file or are otherwise targeting.

segment.source: Don't put x:Uid on property elements, that isn't allowed in Windows Runtime XAML.
segment.target: Don't put x:Uid on property elements, that isn't allowed in Windows Runtime XAML.
